g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
In(OH)3/In2O3 nano -plates and -tubes were prepared by thermal
hydrolysis of indate ionic liquid.
Photoreforming by small sized In(OH)3/In2O3 (1:1) nanotubes yields H2 up to 3.72 mmol h 1. Presence of IL on the nano-objects surface is the driving force for
enhancing of the H2 generation.

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
In(OH)3/In2O3 Nano-objects
H2 generation Ionic liquids
a b s t r a c t
In(OH)3/In2O3 nano-objects (plates and tubes) were prepared under controlled mild reaction conditions by simple basic thermal hydrolysis of 1-(2-methoxy-ethyl)-3-methyl imi-
dazolium tetrachloro-indate (BMIOMe$InCl4) ionic liquid (IL). As the reaction temperature increased from 10 C to 80 C, there was not only an increase in concentration of In2O3 but the growth of nano-tubes (NTs) also increased. At 10 C, 30 C, 50 C, and 80 C, 25.2 ± 7 nm
sized nanoplates (NPls), small nanotubes (26.6 ± 6 nm in length and 8 ± 2 nm in width), NTs
with a length of 25.9 ± 6 nm, and larger nanotubes (49.2 ± 18 nm) were obtained, respec-
tively. The surface concentration of In(OH)3 decreased with the augmentation of the reaction temperature (from 100% at 10 C to 5.1% at 80 C). The nano-objects displayed a band
gap of 5.4 eV, which is in the range expected for photo-catalytic activity to generate
hydrogen from alcoholic solutions. Remarkably, In(OH)3/In2O3 catalyst prepared at 30 C revealed 3.72 mmol h 1 of rate of hydrogen with apparent quantum yield of 16.3%, yielding a
total H2 productivity of 57.6 mmol (5.76 mmol/g) after 32 h. This is the most active semiconductor photocatalysts reported so far of bare indium-based. The presence of In2O3 inside the nano-tubes is also important for the photacatalytic activity of the In(OH)3 based
J. Dupont).
ons LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
semiconductor. The presence of the IL layer not only acts as a template to control the
structure of the nano-objects, but its presence also induces H2 generation.

Experimental studies

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The production of hydrogen from water photolysis is one of
the key solutions for the development of green and sustain-
able energy supplies and it is under intense investigation [1,2].
Indeed, since an earlier report that semiconductors can
performwater photolysis, a huge profusion studies have been
investigated to obtain more active photocatalysts that can
operate under visible light with higher quantum yields.
However, most of the cases reported so far involve semi-
conductor (TiO2, ZnO, tantalum oxides, and N-doped carbons, for example) loading with transition metal nanoparticles (Au,
Pt, Ag, and Cu, in particular) [3e15]. Although significant
achievements have been reported for the production of mi-
cromoles, and in some casesmillimoles, of hydrogen per hour,
most only operate efficiently in the presence of a sacrificial
donor (usually alcohols) to overcome the kinetic barrier of the
oxidation. The oxidation of the sacrificial agents usually
contributes to the generation of the desired product and,
hence, it does not accurately quantify the reduction products
(photo-reforming instead of water splitting) [16,17]. The size
and shape of the semiconductors also plays an important role
in the photocatalytic performance [18,19]. In(OH)3 is an important n-type wide-gap semiconductor material with a
direct band gap of 5.15 eV, and it is a promising material for
photo-applications. In particular, it has great potential in
photocatalysis, such as H2 evolution from water splitting, due to the strong redox ability of the conduction band (CB) elec-
trons ( 0.93 V vs. NHE) and the valence band (VB) holes (4.24 V vs. NHE) [20]. Bare In(OH)3 of various shapes, such as nanosheets, spheres, nanorods, and nanocubes, can usually be
prepared via hydrothermal routes, albeit at relative high
temperatures [21e31].
Therefore, In(OH)3may constitute an adequatematerial for the investigation of the influence of nano-structure shapes on
their photocatalytic properties. In this respect, it was reported
that nearly monodisperse single-crystalline In(OH)3 nanocubes and other polyhedra display H2 evolution from methanol photo-reforming, which is higher than P25-titania, albeit
the shapeeproperty relationship still needs to be fully ach-
ieved [32]. Moreover, most of the contributions reported so far
are related to the photocatalytic properties of doped In2O3 (Table S2) [20,33e43]. Themain goal of this contributionwas to
determine the nano-object shape effect on the photocatalytic
properties of the water splitting. For this purpose, we devel-
oped a very simple and reliable ionothermal method for the
generation of In(OH)3 nano-plates and nanotubes and we investigated their photocatalytic properties (Fig. 1). Herein, we
report that the nano-object morphology has a profound effect
on the H2 generation from methanol reforming, attaining 372 mmolg 1h 1.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text:
The IL 1-(2-methoxy-ethyl)-3-methyl imidazolium tetrachloro-
indate (BMIOMe$InCl4) was prepared according to the literature [44e46]. Indium chloride (InCl3) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. NMR spectra were recorded on a 400 MHz
Varian spectrometer at ambient probe temperature and
referenced to an internal TMS. The FTIR analysis of the ionic
adduct BMIOMe.InCl4 was performed in a Bruker Alpha-P spectrometer. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry
(ESI-MS) was carried out in a Waters micromass Q-Tof
microTM instrument using standard operating conditions,
such as 3.85 kV capillary voltage and 25V cone voltage (positive
mode), or 3.87 kV capillary voltage and 35 V cone voltage
(negative mode) and 80 C de-solvation gas temperature. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) insights were studied
using Q2000 TA Instruments equipment with a heating rate of 10 C min 1. TGA was performed in a Q50 TA TGA operating under a nitrogen gas atmosphere. Transmission electron mi-
croscopy (TEM) micrographs were obtained using a JEOL
JEM1200 EXII operating at an acceleration voltage of 80 kV and
a JEOL JEM2010 operating at 200 kV (CMM/UFRGS). XRD pat-
terns were obtained with an X-ray diffractometer (D-5000 S-
Bruker-AXS, 40 kV, 25 mA, CuKa radiations). X-ray photoelec-
tron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using
a Kratos AXIS Ultra DLD instrument. The chamber pressure during the measurements was 5 10 9 Torr. Wide energy range survey scans were collected at pass energy of 80 eV in
hybrid slot lensmode and a step size of 0.5 eV, for 20min. High-
resolution data on the In 3d, C 1s, N 1s and O 1s photoelectron
peaks was collected at a pass energy of 20 eV over energy
ranges suitable for each peak, and collection times of 5 min,
step sizes of 0.1 eV. The charge neutraliser filament was used
to prevent the sample charging over the irradiated area. The X-
ray sourcewas amonochromated Al Ka emission, run at 10mA
and 12 kV (120 W). The energy range for each ‘pass energy’
(resolution) was calibrated using the Kratos Cu 2p3/2, Ag 3d5/2 and Au 4f7/2 three-point calibration method. The transmission function was calibrated using a clean gold sample method for
all lensmodes and the Kratos transmission generator software
within Vision II. The high-resolution datawas charge corrected
to the reference C 1s signal at 284.5 eV. Apparent quantum
efficiency was calculated as reported earlier [46] employing a
quartz water filter (5 cm) to remove infrared radiation.

sections.heading: Preparation of In(OH)3/In2O3 nano-objects
sections.text:
Typically, in a Schlenk tube, 1-(2-methoxy-ethyl)-3-methyl
imidazolium tetrachloro-indate (BMIOMe$InCl4) (0.25 mmol, 0.1 g) was dissolved in 1 M NaOH (0.75 mL) solution under an
argon atmosphere using hard stirring. Then, the homoge-
neous mixture was heated at the desired temperature for 48 h
in silicon oil. The solution containing a white precipitate was
attained, which was isolated by centrifugation and washed
with acetonitrile (3 5 mL), distilled water (3 5 mL), and acetone (3 5 mL). The obtained white powder was dried under vacuum.

sections.heading: Photocatalytic tests
sections.text:
All photocatalytic reactions were carried out in a quartz
reactor (24 mL). Generally, 10 mg of nano-objects were
dispersed in 10 mL of methanol/H2O solution (1:4). Argon was passed into the solution to remove dissolved air and unde-
sired gases. Afterward, the reactor was placed under soni-
cation for 20 min. Subsequently; the solution was kept under
stirring and degassed again by bubbling with argon for about
10 min to ensure complete removal of air. Finally, the solution
was irradiated using a 300 W arc Xe lamp (operating at 240 W)
and the reaction temperature was kept at 25 C by circulating water around the photo-reactor. H2 generation was evaluated after the desired time by an Agilent 6820 GC.

sections.heading: Preparation and characterization of nano-objects
sections.text:
Ionic liquids (ILs) have been used for the generation of various
types of semiconductor-based nanomaterials with distinct
morphological properties and, hence, have effect on the
enhancement of their photocatalytic activities [46,47]. In
particular, the structural directionality imposed by the IL is
apparently more effective in the generation of structured
nanomaterials if themetal oxide precursor is the IL anion [46].
The simple thermal treatment of BMIOMe$InCl4 [44] with aqueous NaOH affords In(OH)3 with different shapes [nanoplates (NPLs) and nanotubes (NTs)] depending upon the re-
action temperature (Table 3). At 10 C, NPLs with an average diameter of 25.2 ± 7 nm were obtained. Whereas at 30 C, NTs that were 26.6 ± 6 nm in length and 10 ± 3 nm in width were
observed. As the temperature increased, small NTs with
lengths of 25.9 ± 6 nm and 6 ± 2 nm in width at 50 C and large NTs with 49.2 ± 18 nm length and 15 ± 5 nm in width at 80 C were obtained (Fig. 2).
It is important to note that High resolution transmission
electron microscopy images (Fig. 2b) of the NPLs prepared at
10 C showed a lattice fringe spacing of around 0.26 nm that can be indexed to the (101) planes of In(OH)3 [48]. Whereas, NTs prepared at 30 C (Fig. 2d) demonstrated that these tubes consist of an outer layer of In(OH)3 having a lattice fringe spacing of around 0.26 nmfilledwith In2O3with a lattice fringe spacing of 0.30 nm, which can be the lattice spacing of body-
centred-cubic (bcc) In2O3 [49]. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the as-prepared nano-objects at different
temperatures are presented in Fig. S4. All diffraction peaks
can be assigned to the bcc In(OH)3 with the Im-3 space group, which is in accordance with the standard (JCPDS No. 76-1446).
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) analysis (Fig. S5) at around
300 C shows the loss of organic materials (most probably residual IL), yielding 13.6% organic content for the nano-plates
(NPls) prepared at 10 C and 14.7, 12.2, and 14.0% for NTs prepared at 30, 50, and 80 C, respectively. Moreover, 13C CPS NMR spectra of all prepared nano-objects clearly show signals
corresponding to the carbon of the imidazolium cation
(Fig. S6), indicating that the IL forms a stabilizing thin layer
around the nano-objects, akin to that observed for titania and
tantalum ILehybrid materials [46,47].

The specific surface area and pore volumes determined
from the BrunauereEmmetteTeller (BET) isotherms are
summarized in Table 1, which shows that smaller NTs prepared at 50 C have large surface areas (53 m2 g 1) and pore sizes (0.29 m2 g 1) as compared to large NTs prepared at 80 C, which have surface areas of 528 m2 g 1 and pore sizes of 0.17m2 g 1 (Entry 3,4), and NPls prepared at 10 C have surface areas of 59 m2 g 1 (Entry 1).
To understand the chemical composition and surface
defect state of the different In(OH)3/In2O3 samples, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed.
Fig. S9 shows the XPS survey scans obtained for the In(OH)3 samples synthesized at different temperatures. All photo-
emission and Auger peaks observed in the data are indexed in
the upper and lower spectra. The sample surface composi-
tions (Table 1) were obtained using the main emission peak of
each element.
The presence of C, Cl, N, and F is due to the presence of the
IL at the surface of the nanomaterial (Fig. S9), whereas traces
of Na and Si may come from the glassware used during
nanomaterial preparation. The chemical environment of the
In and O surface atoms was investigated by high resolution
XPS data of In 3d and O 1s regions (Fig. 3). The results obtained
from the fittings are displayed in Table 2 and Table S1. The In
3d spectra (Fig. 3a) were adjusted using three chemical com-
ponents, whose contributions clearly changed from one
sample to another. The doublet at the lower binding energies
(444.2 and 451.8 eV) was attributed to the presence of In2O3 at the sample surface. The doublet at 445.1 and 452.7 eV was
related to the In environment within the In(OH)3 lattice, and the third doublet (446.7 and 454.2 eV) was assigned to In atoms
in a non-stoichiometric hydroxide [51e54]. O 1s peak fitting

required three chemical components, and their relative in-
tensities were also varied from sample to sample. An oxide
lattice component was observed at 530.8 eV [55,56]. A second
component at 531.6 eV was assigned to the presence of hy-
droxide as well as oxygen vacancies in the structure [53,56].
The component at the higher binding energy was related to
adsorbed water and organic compounds [53,55].
The XPS results prove that the synthesis temperature af-
fects the chemical environment of both O and In surface
atoms. It is noteworthy that while the surface of the sample
prepared at 10 C consists of only In(OH)3, the formation of relevant amounts of superficial oxide was clearly observed for
the other three samples. Furthermore, with a higher synthesis
temperature, the contribution of the oxide component at both
O 1s and In 3d photoemission regions is higher, whereas the
hydroxide components are lower. It is clear from Table 2 that
the concentration of In(OH)3 decreases with augmentation of the temperature (from 100% at 10 C to 5.1% at 80 C). Moreover, there is a clear decrease in the oxygen vacancies and
hydroxides with the increase in the reaction temperature
(from 92.5% at 10 C to 13.6% at 80 C) (see supporting information Table S1).
The optical measurements were evaluated by diffuse
reflectance spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. 4. In(OH)3/In2O3 prepared at 30 C and 80 C shows only one electronic transition around 240 nm (5.1 eV); however, the samples prepared
at 10 C and 50 C show two electronic transitions due to the electron oscillation perpendicular and along the nano-object
axis [57]. The distinct electronic transitions for samples pre-
pared at 10 C and 50 C can be related to the morphology transition and, thus, their non-stoichiometry surface. Photo-
luminescence (PL) analysis shows two broad peaks for all
gions for the In(OH) 3/In2O3 nano-objects prepared at 10 C, lines represent the Shirley-type background, and the black
ponents In2O3 [50], In(OH)3 (blue), and Inx(OH)y (red). (For

samples [58]. A similar results behaviour was observed for
samples prepared at 30 C and 80 C as that previously observed in UVeVis measurements; however, the samples
prepared at 10 C and 50 C displayed a different behaviour. The sample prepared at 10 C shows the highest PL intensity, whereas the samples prepared at 50 C show the lowest PL intensity. In fact, the morphology/defects induced during the
syntheses of the sample prepared at 50 C led to an efficient suppression of the electronehole pair recombination process.
Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy was utilized to
probe the structural characteristics of the as-prepared
In(OH)3/In2O3, as shown in Fig. S8. Two intense bands at 3225 and 3111 cm 1 were observed, which are attributed to the OH stretching modes of In(OH)3. The bands at 1150, 1060, and 780 cm 1 are assigned to OH deformation modes. Furthermore, the presence of an intense peak at 492 cm 1 probably
corresponds to IneO [59]. From the TG/DSA profile, twoweight
losses can be observed at about 30e310 C and 310e500 C (Fig. S5). The weight loss between room temperature and
~310 C can be attributed to the removal of free and bound water/OH from the surface of the In(OH)3 nano-objects [26], whereas the materials that endothermically lose their weight
prepared at 30 C after its calcination at 200 C (water/methano
from 310 to 500 C can be attributed to the chemical dehydration of In2O3 [60].

sections.heading: Photocatalytic hydrogen generation
sections.text:
Photocatalytic experiments of the prepared In(OH)3/In2O3 nano-objects were performed using H2O in the presence of methanol as a sacrificial agent, without the use of the noble
metal as co-catalyst. Methanol can be oxidized by OH radicals
directly by photogenerated holes on the surface of photo-
catalyst in solution [61]. The reaction was performed in a
quartz reactor vessel using a 300 W Xe arc lamp (operating at
240 W) as the light source, with water circulating in order to
keep the temperature at 25 C. No H2 was detected in control experiments performed in the absence of catalyst and in the dark. The obtained results
under different photocatalysts are summarized in Table 3.
Fig. 5 exhibits the hydrogen evaluation of In(OH)3/In2O3 nanoobjects prepared at different temperatures. In(OH)3/In2O3 prepared at 30 C shows the highest mass-specific activity (3.72 mmol h 1) under full spectrum light, which is significantly larger than nano-objects prepared at 10 C, 50 C, and 80 C,

which generated 2.36, 2.03, and 1.85 mmol h 1 after 4 h of
photolysis. In the absence of MeOH, no H2 production was observed that neglects the possibility to generate H2 from the residual surface IL (Table 3, entry 5).
Therefore, it can be assumed that the best ratio of In(OH)3/ In2O3 is around 1 for methanol photo-reforming. These catalysts revealed superior activities (productivity) [62] to generate
hydrogen as compared to most of the doped In2O3 based catalysts (generally between 0.98 and 376 mmolg 1h 1) usually doped with noble metals (Table 4). Note that the obtained
apparent quantum yield (Table 4, entry 14) is among highest
reported so far (compare with entries 1, 2, 5, 6 and 7, Table 4.
Note that it was reported that photocatalytic activity is
related with the length size and width for nanorodes, which
increases with the increases with the length and width of
nanorodes that prolongs the lifetime of photoexcited charge
carriers in semiconductors [63,64]. In our case, the augmen-
tation on the photocatalytic activity was observed with the
decrease of the length and width of nano-object (Table 3, en-
tries 1-4).
The interaction of ILs and semiconductors may modulate
the band gap of the semiconductors [65,66] and may provide
the driving force towards photocatalytic redox processes by
the creation of a solid semiconductoreliquid junction reduced
by improving the charge separation and tuning the electron/
hole ratio. Interestingly, the presence of an IL layer in these
In(OH)3/In2O3 nanomaterials (Observed by TGA, XPS analysis, and 13C CP-MAS NMR) displays the typical signals of the imi-
dazolium cation in hybrid materials [67,68] also induces the
photo-catalytic generation of H2 (Fig. 5). It is believed that the presence of an IL may act as an electron carrier, causing
electron transfer from the conduction band [69]. When the
highly active In(OH)3/In2O3 catalyst prepared at 30 C was calcinated at 200 C for 1 h to remove some extent of the IL (having only 1.5% IL, Fig. S11) and tested under our standard
conditions, a low amount of H2 was produced (Fig. 5b). In fact, the residual amount of the IL was larger in the samples pre-
pared at 30 C that in others prepared at 10, 50, 80, and 200 C. This is another indication of the role played by the IL on the
surface properties of the semiconductors, as predicted by
theoretical calculations [70].
Moreover, the residual IL may facilitate the contact of the
water/alcohol with the surface semiconductor, akin to that
observed for related hybrid IL-containing materials [46].
Mechanistically, methanol plays a critical role as a sacrificing
agent. It would react with the formed hydroxyl free radical (OH ), produced from the reaction of hþ with H2O at the surface of In(OH)3/In2O3 nanomaterials, resulted in
CH2OH reactive intermediate [73,74]. Besides, hydroxyl group of CH3OH also captures photogenerated holes (h þ) to give
CH2OH. This oxidation product ( CH2OH) is an electron donor that injects electrons to the conduction band to in-
crease the potential for the evolution of H2. It is important to note that a small extent of CO, CH4 and CO2 (2e5%) were also observed in all cases, which are the photoreformed products
of CH3OH. The recyclability of the catalyst (Fig. 6) was also investigated, which showed no decrease in the catalytic ac-
tivity under our standard conditions, yielding a H2 productivity of 5.76 mmol/g (57.6 mmol) for indium nano-objects
after 32 h of irradiation.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
The simple basic thermal hydrolysis of 1-(2-methoxy-ethyl)-3-
methyl imidazolium tetrachloro-indate (BMIOMe$InCl4) IL generated In(OH)3/In2O3 nano-objects with different shapes (plates and tubes) depending on the reaction temperature. The
ratio of In(OH)3 decreased with the augmentation of the temperature (from 100% at 10 C to 5.1% at 80 C). At 10 C, In(OH)3 nanoplates were formed exclusively. With the increase in reaction temperature, In2O3 started to form and the shape gradually changed to small nanotubes and to larger
nanotubes. The thermal treatment at 200 C lead to In2O3. The increase in temperature also leads to the gradual remove of
residual IL. It appears that the interaction of the residual IL
and indium nano-objects provides the driving force towards
photocatalytic redox processes by the creation of a solid
semiconductoreliquid junction reduced via the charge sepa-
ration and tuning of the electron/hole ratio, hence enhancing
the catalytic activity. The productivity obtained by the relatively small In(OH)3/In2O3 (1:1) with a rate of 3.72 mmol h 1 and 5.76 mmol/g after 32 h is larger than those obtained with bare
In-based semiconductors reported so far. It is also clear that
there is no direct correlation between the nano-object surface
area and photocatalytic performance, but there is a relation-
ship between the concentration of indium hydroxide on the
surface and the amount of residual IL. It also appears that the
presence of the In2O3 phase is also required for the photocatalytic performance of the In(OH)3 nano-objects. Indeed,
both bare indium hydroxide and indium oxide showed mar-
ginal catalytic activity. Finally, not only the shape of the nano-
objects plays an important role on the photo-reforming cata-
lytic properties, but the presence of residual IL may also play
an important role as a surface semiconductor modifier.

metadata.abstractText: In(OH)3/In2O3 nano -plates and -tubes were prepared by thermal hydrolysis of indate ionic liquid. Photoreforming by small sized In(OH)3/In2O3 (1:1) nanotubes yields H2 up to 3.72 mmol h . Presence of IL on the nano-objects surface is the driving force for enhancing of the H2 generation. a r t i c l e i n f o
